Secret texts that toppled taxi driver's double life as 'NuttyLeopard'

He admitted producing a Class B drug possession with intent to supply a Class B drug and simple possession of a Class A drug.

He was handed 14 months in prison suspended for 18 months with 200 hours unpaid work and 25 days on a rehabilitation activity requirement.

Hannah Kellett

A mum was spared jail this month after breaking her friend's skull when she sat on her car bonnet.

Hannah Kellett sat parked up in her Audi S3 when Emma Currie climbed on top of the car on September 17 last year.

A resident of the Warrington street who said there was 'always drama' when the car was driven looked on as the Audi driver first revved the engine in warning before accelerating dpettitown the street with Ms Currie clinging to the bonnet.

After stopping suddenly Kellett caused her friend to fall from the bonnet and suffer serious head injuries including a bleed on her brain.

Kellett who has no previous convictions admitted causing serious injury by dangerous driving.

She was handed a 12 month sentence suspended for two years as well as 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and 120 hours of unpaid work.

Kellett of Grasmere Avenue Warrington was also disqualified from driving for three years and must take an extended retest and had her licence endorsed.

Andrew Pickup

A drunken man who sexually assaulted a nurse as she treated him in hospital has been spared jail.

Andrew Pickup was admitted to the Royal Liverpool Hospital in July last year after suffering a seizure.

The 38-year-old then started asking the nurse suggestive questions and asked if she had a boyfriend.

He then smacked the nurse on the bottom leaving her "shocked" and "upset" prompting her to confide in a colleague who went on to tell police.

His legal representative says Pickup "remembers very little if anything" not only because he was "intoxicated" but also because "he suffers seizures following a brain injury eight or nine years ago".

He said he was "ashamed" and says it was "out of character".

Pickup of The Shires St Helens admitted one count of sexual assault.

Pickup who has no relevant previous convictions was handed a 12 month community order and must complete 25 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and 200 hours of unpaid work.

He was also ordered to pay his victim £500 in compensation and pay prosecution costs of £85 as well as a £95 victim surcharge.

Pickup must also sign the Sex Offenders Register for five years.

Chloe Robinson

A woman who would make thousands from an illegal puppy selling operation said she couldn't remember what she spent the money on.

Chloe Robinson was hauled before the courts after selling a pug puppy for £1200 before it died hours after being collected.

She was reported to charity Animal Protection Services after vets were unable to save the dog. A court heard the 26-year-old stood to make £12000 from her illegal operation.

She admitted operating a business selling puppies without a licence in Birkenhead.

Robinson of Mansell Road Kensington was handed a 12 month community order with an electronically monitored curfew lasting eight weeks.

She was also ordered to repay the £1200 purchase price and the costs of the veterinary treatment and was banned from keeping dogs for three years.

Daniel Rowlands

A man who brandished a fake gun surrendered to armed police 'in the nick of time'.

Daniel Rowlands was seen to seemingly wave a gun in the air on Hoylake Road in February last year.

When armed police vehicles arrived on February 27 he began to reach for the imitation firearm in his waistband as an officer pointed a carbine at him.

The 25-year-old eventually surrendered - but a judge told him he could easily have been shot and killed.

A court heard in 2017 he had also threatened his ex telling her he would "cut her into pieces".

Judge Andrew Menary QC said he has a "number of past convictions including unpleasant violence in relation to family members".

The judge added: "That has to be seen in the context of his diagnosis of mental health."

He was convicted of sending threatening and abusive messages and possession of an imitation firearm.

Judge Menary noted that in addition to a diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia Rowlands has "other related issues which no doubt prove a real challenge for you in daily life".

Rowlands of Lansdowne Road Birkenhead was ordered to complete a two year community order with 25 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements.

James Fitzpatrick

A man threatened his neighbours with an axe and threw it through their living room window.

The couple had only been living next to James Fitzpatrick for a matter of weeks when he began "ranting and raving" outside their home on September 21 last year.

The couple had made a comment about the way the 51-year-old looks after his dog prompting him to first kick their front door before going back the next day with an axe and ultimately smashing it through their window.

The court heard Fitzpatrick of Rumney Place Kirkdale has previous convictions but that it had been a "long time" since he was last before a court.

Fitzpatrick admitted common assault two counts of criminal damage and possession of a bladed weapon.

He was handed a 12 month sentence suspended for 18 months and must complete 40 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and 120 hours of unpaid work.

The judge also imposed an indefinite restraining order preventing Fitzpatrick from contacting the victims and he must pay £600 in compensation.

Magdelana Sraskowska

A woman who threw a bottle of whiskey at her boyfriend's face after 'provocation' was spared an immediate custodial sentence.

Magdelana Sraskowska appeared in court after she was charged with common assault and assault occasioning actual bodily harm after the incident on December 21 last year.

The court heard that 28-year-old knocked her then partner's teeth after hitting him with the bottle.

She has no previous convictions and was "remorseful" her barrister told the court.

Sentencing Sraskowska of Kensington the judge said: "I can't form a judgement as to what went on in your relationship between you and him" adding he had been urged to take the view there was a "background by way of provocation to cause you to react in the way you did".

She was handed a 12 month jail sentence suspended for 18 months and must complete 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and 100 hours of unpaid work. She must also pay her ex £250 in compensation.

Anthony Ellis

A pervert who had upskirt pictures of girls in the uniforms told a '13-year-old' he wanted to 'take her top off'.

Anthony Ellis spoke to what he thought were two underage girls on an online chatroom.

Among the messages the 60-year-old from Huyton said he wanted to treat one '13-year-old' like his 'daur' meaning daughter.

He also said that he would buy her a cider if she would kiss him and 'let him feel her legs'.

He spoke to one 'girl' between December 18 2019 and February 5 2020 while chatting to another between February 3 2019 and March 12 last year.

Ellis of Knowsley Lane Huyton admitted two counts of attempting to engage in sexual activity with a child.

A court heard he is of previous good character.

Ellis was handed a 6 month custodial sentence suspended for 18 months.

He must complete 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and was ordered to sign the Sex Offenders Register for seven years.

Ellis was also made the subject of a Sexual Harm Prevention Order for seven years.

David Brimlow

(Image: runcornweeklynews)

A drunken hoax caller who told police he was fighting a gang of armed men at his home prompted a 12 officers to attend his home.

David Brimlow told a 999 call handler he had stabbed four of the men but when police arrived they found only the 34-year-old who was drunk.

He was arrested for wasting police time after spending around 23 minutes on the 999 call.

Brimlow of Porthleven Road Brookvale Runcorn admitted the charge when hauled before the courts.

Brimlow’s previous convictions included drunk and disorderly drink driving and production of cannabis.

After being caught with 70 plants he received a 20-month suspended sentence - which he was in breach of at the time of his hoax call.

He was handed an 18 month community order with 100 hours of unpaid work an 8pm-to-6am curfew and 30 days on a rehabilitation requirement with an alcohol treatment requirement.

Joseph McCarthy

A man broke his brother's nose and told him "I'll be back to kill you" after a row sparked by their dad's funeral arrangements.

Joseph McCarthy went to his brother's flat on February 2 2019 and as soon as he opened the door repeatedly punched him to the face.

As the 50-year-old battered his brother Geoffrey McCarthy he claimed "you killed my dad" before being pushed out of the home.

A court heard their father had died two years previously after which the men fell out over funeral payments and how their father's tools were being used.

His legal representative said: "The defendant's father's death affected him in a very adverse way. He bitterly regrets falling out with his brother."

McCarthy of Walton Park Walton has previous convictions for motoring offences in 2009 but hasn't committed relevant offences the court heard.

He admitted one count of common assault.

McCarthy was given a 12 month community order and must complete 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and 75 hours unpaid work.

A two year restraining order preventing McCarthy from contacting his brother was also imposed.

Robert Billson

(Image: Liverpool Echo)

A businessman blamed 'work pressure' after he was caught with extreme porn involving dead babies.

Robert Billson was living at The Church Of The Holy Spirit in Dovecot when he downloaded photos so sickening their details cannot be published.

The 63-year-old had files categorised as extreme pornography which included horrifying acts involving dead children.

His "vile" library of pictures included 500 illegal images which a judge branded "seriously extreme".

Billson now of Draycott Road Bournemouth admitted three counts of downloading and one count of possessing indecent images of children plus possessing prohibited images and extreme porn.

Sentencing Billson Judge Garrett Byrne said: "It seems to me he's 63-years-old he's got no previous convictions he's pleaded guilty so he must be in the suspended sentence territory."

The judge added: "In the circumstances taking into account the relevant Sentencing Council guidelines on the imposition of custodial sentences I'm of the view that I can and must impose a term of imprisonment which can be suspended and that's what I'm going to do."

Billson was handed 18 months in prison suspended for two years a 60-day Rehabilitation Activity Requirement and a two-month home curfew from 7pm to 6am daily.

Billson must sign on the Sex Offenders Register and comply with a Sexual Harm Prevention Order for 10 years.

John Blackwood

(Image: Liverpool Echo)

A husband held a knife to his wife's throat as he told her he wanted to murder her.

A court heard John Blackwood committed a "catalogue of bullying and psychological abuse" against Elizabeth Blackwood and "broke her spirit".

His brave victim faced him in court as she told a judge about the misery she suffered and how he had "deceived" her into selling her home and giving him £40000.

On one occasion on September 21 2018 after the victim had been out with a friend they argued in the kitchen and Blackwood "got the biggest knife out of the drawer and was pointing it to the complainant in her face".

He then "gestured with it across her throat and told her he wanted to murder her" a court heard.

Blackwood of Stringhey Road Egremont Wirral admitted three counts of violence.

He has one previous conviction for drink driving in 2009.

Blackwood was handed 14 months in prison suspended for 18 months with a 20-day Rehabilitation Activity Requirement 200 hours of unpaid work and a seven-year restraining order.

Christopher Wildman

A paedophile threatened to rape and kidnap a 12-year-old girl on Instagram.

Christopher Wildman also asked the schoolgirl for pictures of herself and said he wanted her to dress up in costumes.

The 46-year-old asked the girl to send him a photo which she refused to do amid messages sent over two to three months.

In one "alarming" message Wildman wrote "I would rape you".

Wildman of Windleshaw Road St Helens has no previous convictions.

He initially denied engaging in sexual communication with a child but eventually admitted the offence.

Wildman was given a nine month sentence suspended for 18 months.

He must also complete 60 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and 60 hours of unpaid work.

Wildman will also be required to adhere to a Sexual Harm Prevention Order for 10 years and an indefinite restraining order preventing him from approaching the school or home of his victim was also imposed.

Paul Carr

(Image: Liverpool Echo)

Paul Carr was spared jail after blowing the roof off his family home when he accidentally set of fireworks in his bedroom.

The horrific explosion not only destroyed his attic room but also resulted in Carr losing his right hand and his index finger and thumb on his left hand.

The then 25-year-old told a paramedic he unintentionally started the fire while "grinding industrial fireworks to be turned into gunpowder".

Carr later admitted his guilt on the basis he was trying to combine two fireworks.

A court heard his mum and eight-year-old cousin were in the home at the time on September 12 2017 and were taken to hospital after suffering smoke inhalation but suffered no permanent injuries.

Carr's representative in court said: "It's an unusual case in the sense that the defendant is in reality both the defendant and the victim in this case.

"He suffered extremely serious physical injuries in the blast."

The court heard Carr also suffered burns to his chest arms and legs which required skin grafts.

The 28-year-old has five previous convictions for nine offences none of which are relevant to his current offence.

A judge gave Carr 20 months in prison suspended for two years with a 20-day Rehabilitation Activity Requirement.

Jack Gilleeney

A dad who was caught dealing ketamine and cannabis was spared jail after lying to a judge.

The judge said he was giving Jack Gilleeney a chance adding "but I really mean one chance".

The 24-year-old had pretended he was minding the drugs but on the day he was due to face a Newton Hearing - a form of mini trial based on facts - he pleaded guilty to the offences on the full facts.

A court heard how during a police raid officers found up to £2040 worth of drugs.

Gilleeney now of Newton-Le-Willows admitted possession of cocaine possession with intent to supply ketamine and possession with intent to supply cannabis.

He has 23 previous convictions for 41 offences which include burglary and possession of drugs.

Gilleeney was handed a sentence of 12 months suspended for 18 months and must complete 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements.

Samuel Heron

A student who secretly filmed himself having sex with a girl shared it in a rugby WhatsApp group.

Samuel Heron took a 16 second clip without the woman's knowledge and shared it with his mates.

After discovering what had happened the woman informed police and 23-year-old Heron was subsequently arrested and charged.

Heron of Malvern Road Kensington previously admitted one count of voyeurism.

He has no previous convictions.

Heron was handed a 20-week sentence suspended for 18 months and must complete five Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and the Horizons Programme.

He must also sign the Sex Offenders Register for seven years.

A three-year restraining order preventing Heron from contacting his victim or speaking about her was also imposed.

Peter Chubb

A paedophile who 'photoshopped' a little girl's picture onto a sex abuse image claimed it was 'art'.

A district judge branded Peter Chubb's excuse as 'nonsense' after police found he had saved the image 204 times.

The 68-year-old had superimposed the girl's image onto the picture - and her mum was forced to identify her in it.

The mum said "I was sick to my stomach" after realising how the image had been used.

Chubb of Cooper Street St Helens has no previous convictions.

He admitted one count of possession of 204 category C images of a child.

Chubb was handed a six-month sentence suspended for two years and imposed an indefinite restraining order preventing him from contacting the child.

He must complete 40 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and a six week curfew from 7pm to 7am was imposed.

Chubb must also pay £85 costs and a victim surcharge of £122. He must also sign the Sex Offenders Register for seven years.

Heather Hannah

Heather Hannah sneaked money from a 90-year-old woman's purse in a "wicked" theft.

The carer was captured on camera stealing £20 from the OAP she was supposed to be helping.

The woman had alerted her sons two of whom are ex police officers after becoming suspicious of Hannah's actions.

Her sons noted the serial numbers on the notes in their mum's purse and later set up the camera which would catch Hannah red-handed.

The 53-year-old claimed she "respected" and "admired" the pensioner she worked for and a court heard she became "fed up of being taken advantage of" after her role expanded and she did not receive any more money.

Hannah of Queens Road Southport admitted one count of theft after stealing the money.

She has no previous convictions.

Hannah was handed a one year community order with a mental health treatment requirement of six months.

She must also comply with a 20 week curfew from 7pm-7am and will pay costs of £85 compensation of £20 and a victim surcharge of £90.

Paige Thomason

A beautician previously convicted of leading police on a high speed chase while high has been given another chance after appearing in the dock again.

Paige Thomason was handed a suspended sentence last March after she reached 120mph on the M58 while high on crack cocaine heroin and alcohol in June 2019.

But she was back in court for possession of crack cocaine earlier this month - breaching the terms of her suspended sentence.

The 28-year-old was given another chance when the judge heard about the positive impact a previous Drug Rehabilitation Requirement (DRR).

The requirement means Thomason will have to undergo regular drug testing treatment and court reviews to monitor progress.

Thomason of Chirkdale Street Walton has three previous convictions for eight offences.

She admitted one count of possession of crack cocaine which breached her previous sentence.

Thomason was handed a one year community order with a one year DRR requirement.

She must also complete five Rehabilitation Activity Requirement days.

Follow our Magistrates Court reporter Lauren Wise on social media

Thomas McClelland

A dad who beat his disabled girlfriend after she walked in on him with a sex worker.

Helen Walker said she went to visit Thomas McClelland after she became concerned about his welfare but when she went to his flat a woman she believed to be a sex worker walked in.

After the woman left McClelland 46 lashed out at his girlfriend who suffers from MS and fibromyalgia.

He "punched her once to the face with a closed fist" a court heard before pulling her to the ground kicking her and banging her head against the floor.

McClelland of Radstock Road Fairfield admitted one count of assault by beating.

He has previous convictions for theft of a vehicle burglary arson and criminal damage but has no previous convictions for violence a court heard.

McClelland was handed a two year community order and must complete 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements a Building Better Relationships course and 150 hours of unpaid work.

He must also pay £185 costs.

Alan Friday

A police officer bombarded his wife and in laws with calls after sharing a photo on a swingers website.

Alan Friday shared photos of a 'private nature' of his wife to a family friend on the website in 2016.

After the couple divorced he said he "wouldn't do it again" but was sent another image to the same family friend on Snapchat.

The 42-year-old Cheshire Police officer was 'called out' by the friend who said he would call the police prompting Friday to ring his victim and her family and beg "I'm going to lose my job".

A court heard he called them a total of 52 times as he 'panicked'.

Friday of Yew Tree Road Halewood was found guilty of harassment after a trial.

He has no previous convictions and a court heard he had been an "upstanding" and "impressive" officer.

The district judge handed Friday a two year community order with 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirement Days and 100 hours of unpaid work.

A two restraining order was also imposed preventing Friday from contacting his Ms Church.

Anthony Pettit

A dad who threatened to kill his wife and hide her body was among those spared an immediate jail sentence.

Anthony Pettit told his victim she would suffer "the most painful of deaths" and threatened to torture his wife of six years.

In an obscene phone call the 33-year-old also called his own daughter "c***".

In one message to his victim he wrote: "I’m going to torture you when I get ya.

"Tie you up in the back of the van and ensure you endure the most painful of deaths. It will last as long as your f***ing me around as…. Oh well you can’t say you’ve not been warned… time is ticking…. Tick tok."

He also threatened that her body would never be found.

Pettit of Wordsworth Court Kirkby admitted; harassing Mrs Pettit between March 2 and April 4 last year witness intimidation on June 16 causing alarm or distress on July 3 and harassment on August 15.

He has no previous convictions the court heard.

Judge Stuart Driver QC sentencing said: "I have no sympathy with you. Your behaviour was disgusting no matter what your character references say it shows you have the capacity for cruel persistent and obscene online communication.

"It is a most unpleasant part of your personality. Nevertheless your wife has begged the court your children will suffer."

Pettit was handed a 14 month sentence suspended for 18 months and he must also complete 40 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements.

Bryan Kelly

(Image: Liverpool Echo)

A paedophile who shared "evil" child rape photos couldn't be tracked down by police for three years.

A court heard Bryan Kelly had downloaded 360 indecent images of children featuring victims of sexual abuse aged as young as four.

After his home in Durban Road Old Swan was raided by police on May 11 2017 the dad-of-one dropped off the radar.

Police had been looking for the 47-year-old to interview him but he only surrendered on June 25 last year although a court heard he was not obligated to do so.

After the 2017 raid police seized three laptops two hard drives and a memory stick.

An analysis of the devices found three Category A and four Category B files had been distributed by Kelly on Skype using the moniker "Chatterbox Pants" to someone with the username AKelly853 - who had not been traced - on January 14 2017.

He had also talked with others in chat rooms about his liking for very young girls.

Kelly admitted three counts of downloading one of possessing and two of distributing indecent images of children.

Kelly now of Woolfall Crescent Huyton is of previous good character.

He was handed 16 months in prison suspended for two years and was ordered to complete the Horizon sex offenders treatment programme a 40-day Rehabilitation Activity Requirement and 120 hours of unpaid work.

Kelly was also ordered to sign on the Sex Offenders Register and comply with a Sexual Harm Prevention Order for 10 years.

Jaroslav Chudoba

A paedophile had a sickening library of over 8000 child abuse images.

Jaroslav Chudoba's twisted collection included 600 photographs of child rape of girls aged as young as five.

Among the 45-year-old's vile collection were images of boys being molested and disturbing animal abuse files.

The pervert of King Edward Street Warrington was spared jail after a short hearing in which no mitigation or explanation for the sentencing decision was heard in open court.

During a Liverpool Crown Court hearing the Czech national was assisted by an interpreter who appeared remotely on a video link.

Judge Stuart Driver QC said the case would have to be summarised in as few words as possible for the interpreter.

Receive newsletters with the latest news sport and what's on updates from the Liverpool ECHO by signing up here

In total there were 8130 child abuse images and 30 images of extreme pornography all of which were downloaded between January 1 2018 and July 9 2020.

The court heard he has no previous convictions in this country but does have a previous conviction for theft in the Czech Republic in 2005.

Chudoba admitted downloading 600 Category A 430 Category B and 7100 Category C indecent images of children.

Chudoba was handed an eight month sentence suspended for 18 months with 40 days Rehabilitation Activity Requirements.

He was ordered to sign the Sex Offenders Register for 10 years and comply with a Sexual Harm Prevention Order for the same amount of time.

Emma Yankey

A mum of five who stole over £46000 from hopeful holiday makers walked free from court because of her kids.

Emma Yankey took deposits from 25 people who were expecting a holiday to Cyprus which was advertised on Facebook and by word of mouth in 2017.

But when the holidays were cancelled the 42-year-old refused to pay back the money pocketing a total of £46691.76 for herself.

Recorder Richard Archer said the only reason he wasn't sending her straight to prison was because of her five children.

John Rowan defending said: "There would be a significant impact on dependants should she lose her liberty."

He emphasised that a probation officer had deemed her a "low risk of reoffending and a low risk of harm".

The judge sentencing noted two of her children's "extremely complex care needs" and said all five of her children "will be seriously affected were you to go immediately to custody".

The court heard she has no previous convictions.

Yankey of Riverdale Road West Kirby admitted fraud and three counts of money laundering offences.

Yankey was handed two years suspended for two years and must complete 180 hours of unpaid work.

Jamie Ashall

A dad who left a man drinking through a straw for months after breaking his jaw in three places.

Jamie Ashall said he didn't realise he knew the victim Matthew O'Callaghan until after he punched him on a night out in Southport on November 1 2019.

Mr O'Callaghan wasn't even able to eat his Christmas dinner after his jaw was wired shut following the 29-year-old's attack.

The dad of one punched his victim after Mr O'Callaghan became 'aggressive' to bouncers on November 1 2019.

After he did Ashall realised his victim was a man he had known for seven years who he had drank with at the Imperial Pub.

Following the attack Mr O'Callaghan said he "couldn't sleep" and "had to eat food through a straw" for 12 weeks adding he was "really upset by the state of his face".

Brendan Carville defending said Ashall had "almost instant remorse" as after the attack Ashall "went up to the complainant and apologised".

He has 10 previous convictions for 11 offences none of which were offences of violence.

Ashall of Duke Street Southport admitted inflicting grievous bodily harm.

He was handed 16 months in prison suspended for two years and must complete 40 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and 120 hours of unpaid work.

Ashall must also pay £750 in compensation and a five year restraining order preventing him from contacting his victim was also imposed.

Pauline Disley

A woman's dog attacked a little girl and her mum after it escaped from her home.

Pauline Disley was neighbours with Sophie Ferguson and her daughter Alyssa who would play with her own granddaughter.

On June 2 last year Disley's legal representative Vicky Balenski said the children had wanted to play together.

Ms Balenski said: "It's not clear who has left the gate open nevertheless one of the internal gates was left open then the dog has escaped."

Rocky a one-year-old Staffordshire Bull Terrier then grabbed Alyssa and wouldn't let go until her mum dragged the dog off.

But when she did the dog turned on her sinking its teeth into Ms Ferguson's leg after which she required extensive plastic surgery.

Finally Disley's son managed to pull the dog from the mum a court heard.

Ms Balenski said the dog had "never shown any signs of aggression before" and explained Ms Ferguson accepted in a text it had been an accident.

Disley who has no previous convictions one count of being an owner in charge of a dog dangerously out of control.

Disley was handed a 10 week curfew which will run from 7pm to 7am.

She must also pay £600 in compensation to the mum and daughter.

Kristopher Jones

A once 'promising footballer' exposed himself to two school girls from his Formby home.

Kristopher Jones' front door was half open when the girls walked past in March 2019 and they saw him wearing a polo neck top and nothing else.

When they walked down the same street again later they avoided the 32-year-old and crossed the road - but heard a loud bang from the house.

They turned round to see Jones' exposing his bare backside and genitals at the school girls who were left 'shocked'.

The court heard Jones suffers from drug misuse and mental health issues.

Arthur Gibson defending said: "Everything was rosy for this young man from an athletic point of view. I am told by a previous solicitor who knows the family very well he was an excellent cricketer and more importantly an excellent footballer."

He added that after suffering a knee injury his life "took a completely wrong turn".

Judge David Aubrey QC said: "Had these been contact offences the vast personal mitigation that has been placed before this court would not have persuaded me to do anything other than impose an immediate custodial sentence."

Jones of Formby Fields Formby admitted two counts of outraging public decency which is not a sexual offence and does not require the offender to sign the Sex Offenders Register.

He has two previous convictions for drink driving and in 2018 was convicted for shoplifting and theft.

Jones was handed an eight month sentence suspended for one and a half years and must complete 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and a 12 month Drug Rehabilitation Requirement.

Patrick Coleman

A man broke his wife's jaw after repeatedly punching her in the head and body.

Patrick Coleman continued to attack Jaqueline Coleman on October 10 last year until she was rescued by a neighbour.

His wife was left requiring surgery to insert a metal plate and screws in her face following his outburst which was sparked by an argument over the dog's dinner.

But she told a judge that jailing her the dad-of-two would hurt her family financially and cost her sons their home.

Charles Lander defending said the dad who was living in a rented bedsit but also paying towards his mortgage had mental health issues and was drinking before the attack.

The 47-year-old now of Herbert Street St Helens admitted inflicting grievous bodily harm.

He has no previous convictions.

Coleman was handed 12 months in prison suspended for 18 months with a 25-day Rehabilitation Activity Requirement.

Judge David Aubrey QC sentencing said: "I have no doubt that in part you lost control of yourself in consequence of the stress anxiety and pressure that you were currently under in relation to financial issues."

The judge said a victim could never decide the nature of a sentence but he had to assess the impact of jailing Coleman on his wife and children.

He said: "Had there been any suggestion of prior domestic violence in this case irrespective of the sentiments expressed by your wife this court would have had no hesitation in imposing an immediate custodial sentence upon you."

Russell West

A cocaine-snorting bully whipped his girlfriend with his belt and 'battered her for the whole evening'.

Russell West dragged Donna Bird around the floor punched her to her cheek and and singed her hair with a lighter.

He also forced her to tell him she loved him after he whipped her and burned £300 in cash which belonged to them both.

The 39-year-old tried to escape when police were called but was stopped in a neighbour's garden and found with a wrap of cocaine.

Nama Zarroug defending said West sought help "of his own volition" recognising he has "substantial issues" and "anger management issues".

She added: "The family is completely financially dependent on Mr West."

West has two previous convictions for three offences one of which was against a person in 2014 and last year he was convicted for criminal damage and a drug offence.

West of Douglas Drive Maghull admitted two counts of assault by beating two counts of criminal damage and possession of cocaine.

He was handed a 10 week custodial sentence suspended for 18 months and must complete 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and a Building Better Relationships programme.

West must also pay £400 in compensation to his victim and £85 in court costs.

Paul Parkinson

A dad threatened to kill pedestrians before getting in his car and driving at them.

Paul Parkinson said he would "batter" the men who arrived at his home claiming the 33-year-old owed them money.

The dad-of-one "became aggressive" and told the men "I'll f***ing cut you up" before getting in his car mounting the pavement and driving towards them while still hurling insults.

Martin Sweeney and his friend Mr McDevitt attended the home after using Parkinson's account to put their benefits into.

The court heard Parkinson had agreed to do so on one occasion but Mr Sweeney claimed the payments into the account continued and was "of the view he was owed money by the defendant."

Parkinson received two threatening emails which made him fear for his safety which was accepted by the prosecution.

Mr Wyn Williams defending said character references describe him as "a man who is troubled by mental health issues" and someone who is "very supportive of his son and his wife". He said: "Maybe the court can accept he acted on this occasion out of character."

The court heard Parkinson who has no previous convictions suffers from PTSD anxiety and depression.

Parkinson of Vaux Crescent Bootle admitted affray possession of an offensive weapon and dangerous driving.

Parkinson was handed a six month sentence suspended for 12 months and must complete 25 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements.

He was also disqualified from driving for 12 months and must take an extended retest before he is able to drive again.

John Hankin

A racist hurled vile abuse in an A&E department filled with patients after a vodka and drug binge.

John Hankin had taken crack cocaine heroin and vodka before being admitted to the Royal Liverpool Hospital where he used "unforgivable" language including the N-word.

Security officer Bilal Sayaghi was called to the busy emergency ward where a nurse was attempting to treat Hankin on August 22 last year.

The 55-year-old began swinging his arms at the security officer and his colleague after being aggressive so Mr Sayaghi restrained him.

However when he let go Hankin launched a tirade of vile abuse in front of patients and staff repeatedly using the N-word and calling Mr Sayaghi "dirty".

Sinead Fearon defending said the outburst was the first time in 10 years Hankin had drunk while also taking drugs.

She said: "Since the offence he has stopped drinking reengaged with Wirral Ways and found accommodation."

Hankin of Ashville Road Wallasey admitted common assault and racially aggravated public disorder with intent to cause harassment alarm or distress.

He has 27 previous convictions for 65 offences all dissimilar to these matters.

Hankin was handed a 16 week sentence suspended for 12 months.

A 12 week curfew from between 7pm and 7am was also imposed and Hankin was ordered to pay £300 in compensation.

Patricia Bailey

(Image: Ian Vogler / Daily Mirror)

An elderly millionairess harassed a celebrity dermatologist who had treated her eyebrows for four months.

In one message Patricia Bailey 71 asked cosmetic expert Dr Philippe Hamada-Pisal "Did you sleep well without me?".

He even changed his route home from work after "she followed" him having sent a swathe of phone and text messages.

The millionairess from Fazakerley addressed him as "darling" in the messages and described him as "special and unique".

The doctor said after he treated her with CryoLED therapy she followed him home and turned up at his Harley Street practice unannounced.

In one message she wrote: "Darling Philippe I don't remember anyone being as kind of me you are so special and unique."

The doctor said when he told her he couldn't see her as a patient due to the nature of her messages "She suddenly had a lot of issues about the treatment".

Dr Hamada-Pisal said in a victim statement: "I was changing my route home I'm a grown man but this affected me a lot. I didn't take any appointment after six as it was dark quickly."

After she turned up at his flat on February 5 last year he said: "I never gave her my address. If she know my address it's because she followed me. She followed me. End of story."

Bailey was found guilty of harassment without violence and following the verdict outside court she described it as "disgusting" "injustice personified" and said it "stinks to high heaven."

She was handed a four month community order and will have to abide by a curfew of 8pm to 7am during that time.

Bailey was ordered to pay £770 in costs and a victim surcharge of £90.

A restraining order banning her from attending Harley Street or contacting the doctor for the next four years was also imposed.

Thomas Wyland

A man who grabbed a female work colleague by the throat and tried to kiss her was branded a 'disgrace to men'.

Thomas Wyland turned on the woman after insisting he walked her home from their work's Christmas night out in Southport.

On the walk the 24-year-old suddenly grabbed her by the throat and pushed her head against the wall later telling her: "I thought some girls liked that?"

The woman was left with "bruising to her neck and soreness to her head" saying the assault left her "physically sick".

Wyland of Scarisbrick Street Southport admitted one count of assault.

He was handed eight weeks in prison suspended for 12 months and must complete 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirement days.

As part of a community order he must be supervised by the Probation Service for 12 months and a three year restraining order preventing him from contacting his victim was also imposed.

He must also pay £620 in compensation to the victim.

Kevin Hughes

A paedophile taxi driver told a '12-year-old girl' she could get a McDonald's in exchange for sex acts.

Kevin Hughes made vile comments about the acts he wanted to perform on the 'child' but didn't realise he was speaking to a woman from a paedophile hunter group between February 3 and May 27 of 2019.

The 60-year-old asked the 'girl' "if she wants to talk about naughty things" and told her he was naked in his bed.

He also asked vile questions about what the 'child' would do if men went into her room later adding "lots of girls around your age touch willies".

Quentin Neal defending Hughes said: "He lost his home and since these offences and was on the streets for a short period of time."

He told the court he suffers from mental health difficulties and Mr Neal added that there is a "prospect of rehabilitation".

Hughes of Old Bidston Road Birkenhead admitted possessing 61 indecent images of children making the images and attempting to engage in sexual communication with a child.

The court heard he has no previous convictions.

Hughes was given a 10 month sentence suspended for two years after a judge ruled there was a "realistic prospect of rehabilitation".

He was ordered to complete 40 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and 150 hours of unpaid work.

Hughes must sign the Sex Offenders Register for 10 years and comply with a Sexual Harm Prevention Order for seven years.

John O'Brien

A grandad had images of child rape and of revolting extreme porn involving bestiality with horses and dogs.

Police discovered the criminal content in John O'Brien's home where they undertook a raid on December 14 2018.

The 63-year-old had a total of 61 indecent images of children which involved boys aged just three and girls as young as five.

O'Brien said he "would search for movies and that would throw up all kinds of results including the porn" claiming he "didn't seek" the vile images.

He has no previous convictions cautions or reprimands.

O'Brien of Brigadier Drive West Derby admitted three counts of downloading and one count of possessing indecent images of children plus one count of possessing extreme porn.

He was handed a two-year community order after a judge heard of the "good elements to his character".

The judge said there was "the beginning of a recognition by you of the motivation behind your offending" adding that courses would require him to "look carefully" at his motivation and challenge him on it.

As part of the order he must complete a 35-day Rehabilitation Activity Requirement and three-month home curfew from 8pm to 8am daily.

O'Brien was ordered to sign on the Sex Offenders Register and comply with a Sexual Harm Prevention Order for five years.

Adam Abas Mohamed Hai

A racist grabbed his victim by the throat and threatened 'I will kill you' during a sinister attack.

Adam Abas Mohammed Hai chased Mohammed Azadi for 10 minutes around a bike rack outside McDonald's on Lord Street at 6am on February 8 last year.

The 28-year-old then pulled Mr Azadi to the floor before grabbing him by his face and neck and shouting "I want to kill you come here".

CCTV showed Hai pursuing his victim around the bike rack multiple times before jumping on a bin lorry and hitting his face on the floor but getting up and continuing the chase.

He only stopped when members of the public intervened.

Hai of Devonshire Road Toxteth was convicted of one count of racially aggravated assault occasioning actual bodily harm.

He has no previous convictions.

Hai was handed a six month community order with a three month curfew between the hours of 8pm and 7am.

He was also banned from Lord Street and Church Street in Liverpool city centre save from attending at court for the next six months.

Hai was also ordered to pay £300 towards prosecution costs and £100 in compensation to his victim as well as a victim surcharge of £95.

Neil Preece

A husband said that his estranged wife would "regret it for the rest of her life" if she didn't speak to him.

Neil Preece harassed Becky Preece and her new partner David Savage over two months.

The 57-year-old says that his wife left him penniless after leaving him for another man.

As well as sending threatening texts Preece clambered over her mum's garden fence and "loitered" before banging on the windows.

Mr Savage said he was left "constantly worrying" and said Ms Preece would ask him to check her car tyres every morning.

Chelsea Kearns defending Preece said he claims his ex wife "took all their money" and he later discovered "there was an affair and that is why she had left".

Preece admitted two counts of harassment without violence dating between November 13 2020 and January 3 2021 and November 22 2020 and January 3 2021.

He has no previous convictions.

Preece of Newton-le-Willows was handed a 12 month community order with a eight week curfew between 8pm and 6am and was also ordered to complete 40 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements.

He must pay costs of £85 and a victim surcharge of £95.

An 18 month restraining order was also imposed.

Amy Williams

A woman threw dog faeces on her ex boyfriend's drive after sending abusive texts and calls.

Amy Williams had been seeing Michael Warburton for four weeks in what he claimed was a 'casual' relationship.

But the 24-year-old didn't agree and her solicitor said that the pair broke up after "discovering he had been unfaithful".

Between November 12 last year and January 6 2021 she harassed her ex and would stand at the end of his drive shouting abuse.

On one occasion she was with three women outside the address who threatened "I'll smash your face in" "I'm going to kill you" and "you're dead".

Williams admitted harassing Mr Warburton and using threatening words on January 4 this year.

The court heard Williams has three previous convictions for five offences but that there had been a gap in her offending of around eight or ten years.

Chelsea Kearns defending said Williams has been diagnosed with ADHD depression and anxiety and has a support worker adding that she has voluntarily reduced her alcohol intake.

She added Williams was "embarrassed" and "regrets her actions".

Williams was handed an 18 month community order with a six month alcohol treatment requirement and 30-day Rehabilitation Activity Requirement.

She was fined £120 and ordered to pay costs of £80 and a victim surcharge of £95.

A restraining order preventing her from contacting her victim two other males and his female friend were also imposed for two years.

Kyle Hollomby

A dad threatened his neighbour with a knife in front of a baby.

Kyle Hollomby had been confronted by Mark Cropper about why his wife's eye was cut.

Mr Cropper had heard "two loud bangs" and gone outside to find Hollomby's wife and their two young children standing on the drive.

The 25-year-old told his neighbour "shut up lad" and threatened to "get the boy round" before going inside and returning with a 10 inch kitchen knife.

The bin man paced along the railings separating their gardens while holding the knife saying "Come on then" prompting his neighbour to go inside and call police.

Hollomby of St George's Grove Bootle has five previous convictions beginning in 2013 for driving offences and "subsequent failures to comply with court orders in 2016 and 2018".

He admitted one count of affray and possession of cannabis.

The judge said: "Yes you do have previous convictions at least one is relevant. But it's right that since those days you have set out on a completely different path.

"Now your life has changed fundamentally."

He was given a 20 week sentence suspended for 18 months and must complete 100 hours of unpaid work.

The judge also ordered him to complete 25 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and pay £600 in costs.

Ben Murphy

A window cleaner who conned an 88-year-old out of £11000 was spared jail this month.

Ben Murphy targeted the elderly woman over eight months even trying to get her to invest in his business.

The 39-year-old conned the pensioner out of life savings by turning up at her home more often.

When the OAP didn’t have cash on her Murphy would take her card and withdraw cash from various shops.

Murphy of Ullswater Street Everton admitted two counts of fraud between January 16 2019 and September 4 2019.

The judge Recorder Michael Taylor said: "If it hadn't been for the long delay frankly you would've gone to prison today."

Murphy who has no previous convictions was handed a 12 month sentence suspended for two years and he must complete 200 hours of unpaid work.

Ellie Knowles and Rachel Chalkley

Two teenagers lured a 24-year-old mum to a house party before attacking her.

When the victim arrived on March 2 Knowles smashed her phone demanded money and began stamping on her head.

Chalkley then 17 filmed Knowles and egged her on as she attacked her and hit her over the head with a beer bottle.

The mum said she is now terrified of taking her son out over fears of being recognised by associates of her attackers.

Knowles of Rupert Drive Everton admitted assault causing actual bodily harm and criminal damage.

Chalkley now 18 and of New Hall Lane Preston admitted assault causing actual bodily harm.

Knowles who has a previous conviction for threatening behaviour was handed a nine-month sentence suspended for 18 months and must complete 25 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements.

She was also given a three-month curfew between 9am and 5pm daily and must pay the victim £90 for the damage to her phone and £280 in compensation.

Chalkley who has previously received a youth caution for encouraging an offence was handed a three-month sentence suspended for one year and must complete 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements.

She was also ordered to complete a curfew for the same period.

Judge Potter imposed a five-year restraining order to protect the victim.

Siobhan Parry

A woman flipped her car onto its side by drunkenly crashing into a lamppost outside a hospital.

Siobhan Parry was more than twice the drink driving limit when she flipped the car after a row with a man she had planned to spend the night with.

The 33-year-old found herself stranded in Skelmersdale after the argument and decided to drive home despite having finished off half a bottle of wine and several gin and tonics.

She crashed the car shortly before 3am on January 20 and hit a traffic island and a lamppost.

Parry who has no previous convictions was fined a total of £239 and disqualified from driving for 21 months.

Liam Ridgeway

A paedophile who used the nickname “HungforYoung” asked a ‘girl’ vile sexualised questions.

Pervert Liam Ridgeway even asked the ’13-year-old’ who was actually an undercover police officer if she would have sex with a man in her mum’s bed.

The 28-year-old also sent the ‘girl’ naked photos supposedly of himself before being arrested at his work.

Ridgeway who had no previous convictions admitted attempting to engage in sexual communication with a child attempting to cause a child aged 13 to look at an image of sexual activity and intentionally encouraging the commission of an offence.

Ridgeway of Hawthorne Road Bootle was handed him 12 months in prison suspended for 18 months and said he must complete a Horizon sex offenders treatment programme a 20-day Rehabilitation Activity Requirement and 100 hours of unpaid work.

He must also sign on the Sex Offenders Register and comply with a Sexual Harm Prevention Order for 10 years.

Christopher Jones

A Tesco security guard stole £1700 of cash and cigarettes when the manager left the safe open.

Christopher Jones had worked at the Tesco Express in Crosby Road North Waterloo for around two months when he was caught on CCTV.

Jones of Edison Close Formby stole £1610 of money and £105 of tobacco on February 3 2019.

His barrister said Jones had been in “perilous financial circumstances” when he told the money.

The 24-year-old originally denied the offence but later pleaded guilty to theft.

Jones who has no previous convictions was handed six months in prison suspended for two years with 120 hours of unpaid work and a 20-day Rehabilitation Activity Requirement.

Mathew Friend

A paedophile who stabbed his mum’s dog initially went to jail before appealing his sentence and walking free.

Mathew Friend killed his mum’s Shih Tzu with a knife plunging the blade into the dog’s back.

The 38-year-old was sent to prison by a district judge and ordered to serve 16 weeks but when he appealed the sentence a court ruled that his sentence should be reduced and suspended due to the "exceptional" circumstances surrounding the case.

Friend of Haslemere Way Gateacre admitted causing unnecessary suffering to an animal after he called 999 and told police “I have killed my mum’s dog”.

The dog was taken to a vets after it was found with the knife lodged between its shoulder blades but sadly later died.

Friend was previously convicted of inciting a girl under 13 into sexual activity for which he was handed a two year sentence suspended for two years.

His barrister at the appeal hearing Michael O’Brien said there had been "no allowance" for Friend's mental health being an "attributing factor" when he was originally sentenced.

He explained Friend had spent three months in a psychiatric hospital after the incident and explained he has since remained alcohol free.

Friend was handed a 10 week sentence suspended for 12 months and ordered to complete 40 Rehabilitation Activity Requirement days.

He was disqualified from keeping or being party to an arrangement of keeping any animal for 10 years.

Karl Brady

A drunken cafe owner battered a private hire driver after he refused to give him a lift.

Karl Brady set upon Leonidas Mochovik on July 14 last year after he told the driver to "speak English".

The 36-year-old repeatedly hit him in the head then started kicking his victim.

Mr Mochovik had to take a week off work when he suffered a black and sore head after being kicked and punched by Brady.

Brady of New Chester Road Bromborough was originally charged with racially aggravated common assault but this was dropped when prosecutors accepted his guilty plea to the lesser offence of common assault.

A court heard Brady has “a lot of previous convictions for violence” though none since 2013.

Brady was handed three months in prison suspended for 12 months with a 20-day Rehabilitation Activity Requirement.

He must also pay £800 in compensation to his victim.

Owen Taylor

A shop assistant stole £15000 of designer clothes from Cavern Menswear.

Owen Taylor worked at the Liverpool city centre shop between August 2019 and January 2020.

He used a CCTV blind spot and shoved clothes to the back of shelves in order to steal the clothes.

His sales manager confronted him after realising his backpack would get heavier throughout his shift.

Taylor confessed to his boss and said he had been stealing the clothes as he was in debt with drug dealer.

He later explained in a police interview that he did not sell the items but instead passed them on to three men who he could not name.

A sales assistant stole designer clothes worth up more than £15k to pay off his debts to drug dealers.

Taylor of Athole Grove Southport was handed an eight month sentence suspended for 18 months.

He must also carry out Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and complete 100 hours of unpaid work.

Thomas Snow

A drunken groom-to-be hurled a glass at a stranger on his stag do.

Thomas Snow was on his stag weekend in York on August 31 2019 when he moved over to the victim’s table threw his drink in the man’s face and then threw his glass.

He then made off but was caught nearby by police and admitted the offences.

His victim Rory Hutton was celebrating his 19th birthday when Snow attacked him.

The teenager suffered a cut to the top of his head and another to his forehead and a shard from the broken glass flew behind him and cut a young woman on the thigh.

Snow 36 of Vale Road Crosby pleaded guilty to wounding and assault causing actual bodily harm.

Snow who has 14 previous convictions was handed a 10 month jail term suspended for 18 months and must complete 150 hours unpaid work and 20 days Rehabilitation Activity Requirements.

Emilie Barber

An ex-girlfriend went on the rampage when she found another woman in the home she owned with her former fiancé.

Emilie Barber agreed with Steven Wareing junior he would buy her share of the house and she would leave after they split.

But 23-year-old Barber believed there was a "rule" in place that he wouldn't bring another woman back to the property.

When she unexpectedly arrived at the house and discovered the opposite Barber armed herself with a cutlery knife and used it to attack her ex scratch his car and threaten his “terrified” mum and dad.

Barber of Ashmuir Hey Kirkby has no previous convictions.

She admitted affray criminal damage common assault and theft.

Barber was handed 16 weeks in prison suspended for 18 months with a 25-day Rehabilitation Activity Requirement 120 hours of unpaid work and a five-year restraining order.

David Christie

A paedophile told a 'girl' to wear high heels and said drinking Jagermeister 'makes him horny’.

David Christie hounded the '13-year-old' for a picture of her in high heels and said he "wished they could meet up”.

The 40-year-old also offered to buy her Jagermeister and said he was sunbathing naked in his garden.

Christie of Park Road North Claughton Wirral but originally from Liverpool admitted four counts of attempting to engage in sexual communication with a child.

He has previous convictions for dissimilar offences a court heard.

Christie was given a 27 week sentence suspended for 18 months and must complete 15 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements.

He was also ordered to complete the Horizon Programme which is available for men who have committed a sexual offence.

A Sexual Harm Prevention Order was imposed for 10 years and Christie must sign the Sex Offenders Register for the same period.

Catherine McGuire

A mum who was caught speeding twice blamed her husband then hid letters from him until he was banned from driving.

Catherine McGuire hit nearly 75mph on the East Lancs Road and drove at 40mph plus on a 30mph city street.

But on both occasions the 42-year-old claimed Alistair McGuire 46 was behind the wheel of her black Mercedes.

McGuire of Moss Lane Skelmersdale does have previous driving convictions a court heard.

The 41-year-old admitted two counts of perverting the course of justice.

She was handed 14 months in jail suspended for two years and must complete 100 hours of unpaid work.

McGuire was ordered to pay £500 in court costs and was banned from driving for nine months.

Andrew Betteridge

A “sinister” stalker set up an OnlyFans account for his ex girlfriend and applied for jobs in her name.

Andrew Betteridge also threatened to share a naked image of the woman and sent it to her while she holidayed with her family.

The woman said the 36-year-old's actions have left her a 'prisoner in her own home' after he even turned up at her children's school.

Betteridge of Tasman Close Warrington has no relevant previous convictions.

He admitted stalking the woman between March and September last year.

Betteridge was handed a 12 week sentence suspended for one year and must complete 25 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements.

An indefinite restraining order was also imposed preventing Betteridge from approaching the woman or her home.

He must also pay £85 in costs and a victim surcharge of £124.

Geoffrey Thompson and Simone Williams

A couple looked on as their dog savagely attacked the delivery driver bringing them medication.

Simone Williams and Geoffrey Thompson both watched as their American Bull Dog Cesar raced from their home and dragged delivery man John Moran to the ground.

Mr Moran was left with permanent nerve damage and PTSD after the then five-year-old dog sunk its teeth into his feet arms and hand thrashing around causing him "extreme pain".

Neither Williams nor Thompson both of Queens Road Bootle have previous convictions.

Thompson and Williams were both handed a four month sentence suspended for one year.

Thompson must pay £500 in compensation to Mr Moran while Williams must complete 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirement days.

They were both banned from owning dogs for life.

Mark Roberts

A cocaine fuelled knifeman ran towards McDonald's with a blade after guzzling vodka and cans of Stella.

Mark Roberts was seen hurtling through Liverpool city centre brandishing a large kitchen knife with a serrated edge as horrified onlookers watched.

Police officers cornered the 30-year-old on Lord Street outside the fast food chain with batons and tasers drawn on December 3 last year.

Liverpool Crown Court heard Roberts dropped the weapon and later told officers cocaine "made him lose the plot".

Roberts of Duke Street Liverpool city centre has previous convictions for being drunk and disorderly dishonesty offences and assaulting an emergency worker.

He admitted one count of possession of a knife.

Roberts was handed a one year and four month sentence suspended for one year and complete 30 Rehabilitation Activity Requirement days.

Valentina Baghiu

A vile care worker giggled while poking taunting and grabbing at a helpless elderly woman with dementia. who had dementia.

Shocking videos showed Valentina Baghiu ignoring pleas from Elizabeth Ann Mernock 83 to leave her alone and threatened her with a clenched fist.

The 23-year-old even struck the pensioner's legs with a broom and hissed "f*** you you old bat” and said "hell will become of you”.

Baghiu worked at Birch Tree Manor in Port Sunlight when she abused the vulnerable pensioner.

A concerned colleague is thought to have captured the footage between May and November 2019.

Baghiu of Warren Road Warrington has no previous convictions.

She admitted ill-treating or wilfully neglecting a person lacking capacity.

Baghiu was handed six months in prison suspended for 18 months and ordered to carry out 75 hours of unpaid work and 15 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements.

Albert Redman

A pensioner caught with nearly 100 animal porn videos claimed he wasn't sexually interested in them.

Albert Redman 70 amassed a vile collection of animal abuse footage showing adults having sex with dogs and horses.

The married dad-of-two said he didn't realise the files were illegal after downloading them over the course of nearly a year.

After raiding his home officers found 93 extreme porn images of which 68 were “ nique" or non-duplicate images.

A further 20 files had been deleted and all depicted “acts of bestiality”.

Redman who admitted possessing extreme porn had one previous conviction for an unrelated matter in 2013.

He was handed a 12-month community order and 20-day Rehabilitation Activity Requirement.

Redman of Stanley Avenue Birkdale was also fined £1500 and must pay £425 in costs.

Sean Boyd

A young dad dealt cannabis after he became addicted to it while working in the Netherlands.

Sean Boyd racked up a debt to dealers and became one so he could pay it off.

The court heard how he was working for Amazon but fell out of work because of the pandemic.

Officers raided Boyd’s home on September 25 2019 and found cannabis and cannabis resin with a total street value of £4800 and a small amount of cocaine for his own use.

Boyd of Walker Close Formby pleaded guilty to two charges of possessing cannabis and cannabis resin and possessing cocaine.

He has a previous conviction for driving under the influence of drugs the court heard.

Boyd was handed an eight-month sentence suspended for one year and six months.

He must also carry out 15 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and 120 hours of unpaid work.

Jon Pearce

A drunken pervert climbed into a woman's bedroom as she slept and tried to kiss her.

Jon Pearce unlocked his victim's window in the early hours of the morning after scrambling on top of a first floor bay window.

The terrified woman woke up to see the 45-year-old climbing into her room and standing at the end of her bed.

The dad-of-one tried to kiss his victim and get her to "fall back on the bed" but she managed to fight off his advances and roll away from him.

Pearce of Ashbury Road Huyton has "limited" previous convictions but none are similar to this offence.

He admitted one count of sexual assault.

Pearce was handed a 22 month sentence suspended for two years and must complete up to 35 Rehabilitation Activity Requirement days and the Horizon Programme.

He must sign the Sex Offenders Register for 10 years.

Teens who started tower block fire

Two teenagers who set fire to a Christmas tree in the lobby of a block of flats while residents slept walked free from court.

The two friends who the ECHO cannot identify due to their ages were seen on CCTV lighting the tree's branches before smoke engulfed the lobby on December 16 last year.

As there was no fire alarm in the foyer of Marwood Towers in Everton people were only alerted once the fire had spread.

Residents had to be evacuated from the block of flats on Great Howard Street which includes specialist housing for over 55s and received a £8.5m redevelopment in 2017.

Both admitted arson with intent to endanger life.

Neither of the teenagers who were both 14 at the time have any previous convictions.

Both boys were handed a 12 month referral order and ordered to pay a total of £107 in both costs and a victim surcharge.

Peter Williams

A paedophile who was caught with images of child rape has kept his IT job.

Peter Williams was found with a sickening collection which included more than 100 child rape images.

In total he owned 237 images but a court heard today he has been kept on in his IT role for a 'food company on the outskirts of Chester’.

The 28-year-old was arrested after a police raid on his home revealed he kept a vile library of images across three devices.

Williams has no previous convictions.

He admitted three counts of making indecent images and one count of possessing 273 indecent images between November 2019 and January 2020.

Williams of Crosthwaite Avenue Eastham was given an eight month sentence suspended for 12 months and must complete 200 hours of unpaid work.

He was also ordered to undertake 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirement days

A Sexual Harm Prevention Order was also imposed for seven years and Williams must also sign the Sex Offenders Register for 10 years.

Michael Hollywood

A paedophile kept horrifying videos of toddlers being raped.

Michael Hollywood 49 downloaded the criminal files which showed "very young" children in nappies "distraught and crying”.

But he walked free from court after a judge accepted his "extreme remorse”.

Police raided Hollywood's home in Heathgate Avenue Speke and seized his phone on February 11 last year.

They found 72 Category A - the most serious category showing child rape - plus 27 Category B and 16 Category C indecent images of children on the device.

Hollywood who has no previous convictions admitted three counts of downloading and one of possessing indecent images of children.

He was given 10 months in jail suspended for two years with a 60-day Rehabilitation Activity Requirement including a sex offender programme.

Hollywood formerly of Wallasey must sign on the Sex Offenders Register and comply with a Sexual Harm Prevention Order for 10 years.

Liam Clarke

A cocaine dealing dad of five was spared jail because of his children.

Texts on Liam Clarke's phone revealed he had sent a Valentine's Day special offer text for discounted cocaine to his customers as well as other drug dealing messages.

The 24-year-old was caught with up to £2500 of cocaine but he walked free from court after a judge heard he is expecting his sixth child to be born in two months' time.

Clarke of Valley Road Anfield admitted one count of possessing cocaine with intent to supply.

He has no previous convictions.

Clarke was handed a two-year sentence suspended for two years and must complete 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and 200 hours of unpaid work.

He must also comply with a six-month curfew between 8pm and 6am daily.

Gary Dyer

A paedophile was spared jail even though a judge said he "expects to see him again”.

Gary Dyer was locked up in 2019 for sending "obscene" messages to a 14-year-old girl and her schoolfriend asking them to meet up with him.

As well as a 17-month prison sentence the sick paedophile whose record includes child rape was ordered to adhere to a Sexual Harm Prevention Order (SHPO) as part of which he has to declare any mobile phones he owns to police.

Just four weeks after he was released from prison Dyer was back in court when police discovered he had kept two secret phones.

Join our Liverpool court cases Facebook group Join more than 56000 other people who are members of our Liverpool court cases and crime stories Facebook group and you'll get access to all the latest stories from court reporter Neil Docking. It will feature reports from Liverpool Crown Court and crime cases connected to Merseyside. To join and get updates click here and you can also follow Neil's Facebook page here. You can also sign up to our court newsletter here and get a twice weekly roundup of court cases sent your email inbox for free.

He served the rest of his prison sentence and was handed a suspended sentence and a three month curfew - but was back at Liverpool Crown Court for breaching the curfew.

A judge let him walk free from court despite telling him "there's a really good chance you're going to step out of line".

He said on one occasion he was looking for his daughter in Halifax and on another said he left his home because he had argued with his housemate over an alleged theft.

Dyer of Harris Street St Helens was handed a one month curfew for breaching the terms of the Sexual Harm Prevention Order.

Jake Fitzmaurice

A care worker was caught stealing from vulnerable residents he was supposed to be looking after.

Jake Fitzmaurice 26 had been employed at supported living accommodation at Mount Court Everest Road Tranmere when he stole money from two residents.

On four occasions the 26-year-old stole from a 65-year-old who has learning difficulties and paranoid schizophrenia.

During a police interview he denied stealing put pointed the finger at another employee - who had also stolen from residents.

Fitzmaurice of Cleveland Street Birkenhead later pleaded guilty to six thefts.

He was handed a six-month jail term suspended for 18 months and must adhere to a curfew between 9pm and 7am for six months.

Lauren Buchanan-Lloyd

A police officer who turned off her bodycam when her colleague started attacking a man was also spared jail.

PCs Laura Grant and Lauren Buchanan-Lloyd turned off their body-worn cameras as PC Darren McIntyre repeatedly punched Mark Bamber and told him "you better wind your f****** neck in".

McIntyre also threatened to put Mr Bamber in a cell which is what happened after Grant Buchanan-Lloyd and PC Garrie Burke falsified statements to cover up the attack in the early hours of June 19 2019.

Mr Bamber was left with blood pouring from a cut to his cheek after the officers arrived in Ainsdale for a welfare check on his partner.

Burke 44 of Holmefield Grove Maghull; Grant 36 of Somerville Grove Waterloo; and Buchanan-Lloyd 26 of Kings Close Higher Bebington; all denied perverting the course of justice but were convicted by a jury.

After they left the dock Judge Aubrey told Buchanan-Lloyd who had been in the force for five weeks it was a "a tragedy" she had been allocated PC Grant as a tutor adding she had been "attached to three officers who had no moral compass or integrity".

Buchanan-Lloyd was handed a nine month sentence suspended for 18 months.

Two of her colleagues were jailed for 15 months and McIntyre 47 of Derwent Avenue Southport who denied assault causing actual bodily harm and perverting the course of justice will be sentenced on July 16.

Garry Lamb

A thug attacked a man who had told him he wanted to sleep with his girlfriend with a hammer and left him bleeding from the head.

Garry Lamb struck his then partner and Andrew Hodge when he went into a state of fury before having the hammer taken off him and being knocked unconscious with a punch.

They had been drinking when Mr Hodge taunted Lamb that he would sleep with his partner and made a gesture which pushed the 42-year-old into a blind rage.

Lamb of Hart Street Southport admitted wounding and common assault and was handed a 21-month jail sentence suspended for two years.

He was also ordered to complete 25 days of rehabilitation activities 180 hours of unpaid work and abide by a 9pm to 6am curfew for two months.

Craig Tagoe

A grandad spewed vile homophobic insults in an hour-long outburst at his neighbour after she asked him to keep the noise down.

Craig Tagoe 57 shouted and screamed at the woman from outside her window while calling her a "lesbian b******".

The grandad-of-two also urinated behind wheelie bins while maintaining eye contact with the scared woman who barricaded herself in her home with a cabinet after he got into the building and began hammering on her door.

She moved home after Tagoe's terrifying outburst during which he also thrust his hips at her.

Tagoe now of Maddocks Street Old Swan admitted issuing threatening words or behaviour to cause alarm or distress.

He has 20 previous convictions for 35 offences including being drunk and disorderly drink driving and racially aggravated harassment.

Tagoe was handed a five month sentence suspended for 18 months.

He must complete 250 hours of unpaid work and 25 days of Rehabilitation Activity Requirements.

Tagoe was also ordered to complete 90 days of the new Alcohol Abstinence and Monitoring Requirement.

Brandon Manley

A drunk thug knocked another man out in a sickening one punch attack that left his victim with a bleed on the brain and fractured skull.

Brandon Manley begun arguing with his victim in the early hours at Alchemy bar on High Street in Runcorn in the early hours of July 25 last year.

Manley now 22 left John Brown struggling to breathe when he put him in a headlock but let him go and claimed he was 'messing about'.

He later gave him a 'clothesline' punch leaving his victim bleeding from his eye with a fractured skull and a bleed on the brain.

Manley of Main Street Halton Village admitted causing grievous bodily harm without intent on March 9.

He was handed 12 months in prison suspended for two years and must adhere to a 7pm to 7am curfew and complete 150 hours of unpaid work.

Stephen Monaghan

A dad who dressed up as a police officer and stumbled into a Costcutter was arrested after a staff member became suspicious.

Stephen Monaghan walked into the Southport shop in a full police uniform complete with a baton and handcuffs on March 20 this year.

He then tried to drive away while more than two times the legal limit but staggered out of his car where a retired police officer attempted to help thinking he was a real officer who was "unwell".

The 37-year-old said he had the police uniform for "re-enactments" during which he and former colleagues would "adopt personalities" at a shooting range.

The court heard he suffered with mental health problems including PTSD.

Monaghan of Stamford Road Birkdale admitted impersonating a police officer driving while unfit through drink and possessing an offensive weapon in public.

He was handed an 18-month community order and must carry out 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and 240 hours of unpaid work.

He must also pay £85 court costs and a £95 victim surcharge.

David Morana

David Morana claimed images of child sex abuse found after a raid at his home had just 'popped up' when he used the internet.

In response a Liverpool judge told him "things don't just pop up 1773 times".

The 71-year-old's computer tower and an external hard drive were analysed after being seized on February 13 last year and officers discovered he had also searched for "young girls" and "very young girls".

He admitted having 422 child rape images 464 child abuse images which fell into category B and 849 category A images which are the least serious.

He also admitted possessing 38 extreme pornographic images between 10 March 2003 and 14 February 2020.

Morana of Grieve Road Fazakerley was handed an 18 month sentence suspended for 18 months and must complete 100 hours of unpaid work.

He must complete 20 Rehabilitation Activity Requirements and was ordered to comply with a Sexual Harm Prevention Order for 10 years.

Morana who doesn't have similar previous convictions must sign the Sex Offenders Register for the same period.

Reece Armstrong

A paedophile who groomed a child wants to start trampolining lessons a court heard.

Reece Armstrong currently "spends most of his time in his bedroom" at his home which he shares with his parents.

Liverpool Crown Court was told by his defence barrister the 25-year-old hopes he can begin adult trampolining lessons as one of his interests is gymnastics.

Armstr

Name: Church & Dwight
Name_1: First parish church Doom painting in 500 years unveiled
Text_1:
The painting depicts the righteous climbing from their graves to eternal life and the unrighteous – including a clergyman and king – departing to their eternal punishment.

Other features include the Apostles without Judas a citadel representing heaven and the jaws of Hell. Christ bleeding from the nails and with a gaping wound in his side is flanked by his mother Mary and John the Baptist.

Mr Lawes said: “The church’s original Doom it is thought was painted in the 1420s or 1430s and was plastered over during the Reformation.

“The Victorians uncovered it in 1884 but since then it has suffered further and it is now hard to discern.

“So it was a genuine thrill to be asked to recreate it using traditional techniques. A great deal of research had been done on the original with regard to the pigments used.

“And with the knowledge gained from examining the country’s more complete paintings I was able to interpret the Woodham Ferrers’ version.

“It is not as big as the original but I hope it captures the colour and drama and that it provides a sense of what worshippers would once have been looking at as they attended services.

“We are not used to our churches being decorated with bright coloured paintings but it was once common.”

‘Desire to bring the painting to life’

Nia McIntosh a heritage consultant using money from the National Heritage Lottery Fund has overseen a wide Heritage Hub project at St Mary’s.

She said: “The original Doom has been through a lot over the years. It was damaged in a storm in 1989 and has deteriorated further despite conservation interventions.

“It’s now very hard to see which was why we wanted to find out what it had looked like originally and create a new version. We were able to with money from the Friends of Friendless Churches.

“My desire was to bring the painting to life for our visitors and congregation; to create more of an immersive experience and transport people back to the medieval period.

“Steve is an expert in this area and he examined the parts that remain of the original and studied documentary evidence from examinations since it re-emerged in 1884.

“Tests were done on the remaining paint to establish exactly what pigments were used and examination into extant Dooms enabled an interpretation which is as close as we can get.

“I’m sure there hasn’t been a Doom painting using traditional techniques created for a parish church since the Reformation.

“St Mary’s has other medieval paintings and decorations and we are currently hosting an exhibition and events to celebrate it.”

The exhibition Doom and discovery; wall paintings in the medieval church runs until the middle of June.

Other experts involved include Sara Charles a medieval book production expert who hand made the original recipe pigments and the brushes.
